An A-module M is called a free A-module if it has a basis, i.e., a free system of generators. In this case, every element x in M admits a representation x = sum_{i in I} a_i x_i with coefficients a_i in A that are unique.
The rank of an A-module M is defined as the supremum of all numbers n such that there exists a linearly independent system of elements x_1, ..., x_n in M.
Does the concept of a/an Free A-module need to be defined for a definition of a/an Rank of an A-module to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
To determine if the concept of a Free A-module is necessary for defining the rank of an A-module, we need to analyze the definitions provided:

1. The rank of an A-module M is defined based on the existence of a linearly independent system of elements in M. It does not explicitly require that M be a free A-module; it only requires the existence of some linearly independent sets of elements.

2. A Free A-module is defined as an A-module that has a basis, which is a maximal linearly independent system. While a free A-module certainly has a well-defined rank (equal to the cardinality of its basis), the concept of rank itself does not necessitate that the module be free. The rank can be defined for any A-module by considering the largest size of any linearly independent subset, regardless of whether the module has a basis or not.

Therefore, the concept of a Free A-module is not necessary for the definition of the rank of an A-module. The rank can be considered and calculated even if the module is not free, as long as it contains linearly independent subsets.
